refnamediv.refpurpose: Escapes special characters in a string for use in a SQL statement

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: This function will escape special characters in the unescaped_string, taking into account the current character set of the connection so that it is safe to place it in a mysql_query. If binary data is to be inserted, this function must be used.
mysql_real_escape_string calls MySQL's library function mysql_escape_string, which prepends backslashes to the following characters: NULL, \x00, \n, \r, \, ', " and \x1a.

example.title: Simple mysql_real_escape_string example
example.programlisting:
<?php
// Connect
$link = mysql_connect('mysql_host', 'mysql_user', 'mysql_password')
    OR die(mysql_error());

// Query
$query = sprintf("SELECT * FROM users WHERE user='%s' AND password='%s'",
            mysql_real_escape_string($user),
            mysql_real_escape_string($password));
?>

refsect1.para: This function must always (with few exceptions) be used to make data safe before sending a query to MySQL.

note.para: If magic_quotes_gpc is enabled, first apply stripslashes to the data. Using this function on data which has already been escaped will escape the data twice.

refsect1.para: If this function is not used to escape data, the query is vulnerable to SQL Injection Attacks.

example.title: An example SQL Injection Attack
example.programlisting:
<?php
// Query database to check if there are any matching users
$query = "SELECT * FROM users WHERE user='{$_POST['username']}' AND password='{$_POST['password']}'";
mysql_query($query);

// We didn't check $_POST['password'], it could be anything the user wanted! For example:
$_POST['username'] = 'aidan';
$_POST['password'] = "' OR ''='";

// This means the query sent to MySQL would be:
echo $query;
?>
example.screen: SELECT * FROM users WHERE name='aidan' AND password='' OR 1=1
example.para: This would allow anyone to log in without a valid password.

example.title: A "Best Practice" query
example.para: Using mysql_real_escape_string around each variable prevents SQL Injection. This example demonstrates the "best practice" method for querying a database, independent of the Magic Quotes setting.
example.programlisting:
<?php
// Quote variable to make safe
function quote_smart($value)
{
    // Stripslashes
    if (get_magic_quotes_gpc()) {
        $value = stripslashes($value);
    }
    // Quote if not integer
    if (!is_int($value)) {
        $value = "'" . mysql_real_escape_string($value) . "'";
    }
    return $value;
}

// Connect
$link = mysql_connect('mysql_host', 'mysql_user', 'mysql_password')
    OR die(mysql_error());

// Make a safe query
$query = sprintf("SELECT * FROM users WHERE user=%s AND password=%s",
            quote_smart($_POST['username']),
            quote_smart($_POST['password']));

mysql_query($query);
?>
example.para: The query will now execute correctly, and SQL Injection attacks will not work.

note.simpara: mysql_real_escape_string does not escape % and _. These are wildcards in MySQL if combined with LIKE, GRANT, or REVOKE.

refsect1.para: See also mysql_client_encoding, addslashes, stripslashes, the magic_quotes_gpc, and the magic_quotes_runtime directive.
